The thing to keep in mind when the SRBs are jettisoned is that they are NOT falling back to Earth, it only looks that way.  The SRBs are still rising albeit at a slower rate (they are not under power now) and seem to be falling because the rocket is still accelerating.  They do of course eventually fall back, but not until later.  It is the same with the fairings.  I only mention this so that people have the correct "mental picture" about what is happening.

I watched this as it came uP the coast, you could see the satellite separate from the second stage and steadily increase it's distance. By the time I saw it the second stage only lasted a few seconds, that's how high it was. It's altitude put it into the sunlight so it was very bright, much brighter than the space station, it passed right in front of me heading NNE. Forgot to mention, I'm in North East Pennsylvania.

"New SRBs" is an intentionally misleading marketing term that the out of touch corrupt government contractors ( i.e. Boeing, Lockheed Martin, ULA, Northrop Grumman etc...)  keep pushing so they can continue to drain American tax payers for as much as they can without actually having to innovate or invent anything new. There is no such thing as a "new" SRB no matter which vehicle you are talking about they all work on decades old super toxic and unstable fuels plastic or rubber based fuels. SRBs are the worst in every way that matters: they have the lowest ISP of all, they can not really be reused, they are the only rocket engines that produce extremely toxic exhaust even when functioning correctly and they produce the most greenhouse gasses of any rocket engines by a large margin. SRBs are basically huge plastic fires accelerated with an oxidizer all packed into the same unstable tube, hence they are extremely unsafe by default once ignited they cannot stopped unlike all other rocket types can.
